raw_text:
Ask Jeeves joins web log market
 
 Ask Jeeves has bought the Bloglines website to improve the way it handles content from web journals or blogs.
 
 The Bloglines site has become hugely popular as it gives users one place in which to read, search and share all the blogs they are interested in. Ask Jeeves said it was not planning to change Bloglines but would use the 300 million articles it has archived to round out its index of the web. How much Ask Jeeves paid for Bloglines was not revealed.
 
 Bloglines has become popular because it lets users build a list of the blogs they want to follow without having to visit each journal site individually. To do this it makes use of a technology known as Really Simple Syndication (RSS) that many blogs have adopted to let other sites know when new entries are made on their journals. The acquisition follows similar moves by other search sites. Google acquired Pyra Labs, makers of the Blogger software, in 2003. In 2004 MSN introduced its own blog system and Yahoo has tweaked its technology to do a better job of handling blog entries. Jim Lanzone, vice president of search properties at Ask Jeeves in the US, said it did not acquire Bloglines just to get a foothold in the blog publishing world. He said Ask Jeeves was much more interested in helping people find information they were looking for rather than helping them write it.
 
 "The universe of readers is vastly larger than the universe of writers," he said. Mr Lanzone said the acquisition would sit well with Ask's My Jeeves service which lets people customise their own web experience and build up a personal collection of useful links. "Search engines are about discovering information for the first time and RSS is the ideal way to keep track of and monitor those sites," he said. It would also help drive information and entries from blogs to the portals that Ask Jeeves operates. There would be no instant sweeping changes to Bloglines, said Mr Lanzone. "Our intent is to take our time to figure out the right business model not to try to monetise it right away," he said. Though Mr Lanzone added that Ask Jeeves would be helping organise the database of 300m blog entries Bloglines holds with its own net indexing technology. "Being able to search the blogosphere as one corpus of information will be very useful in its own right," said Mr Lanzone. Rumours about the acquisition were broken by the Napsterization weblog which said it got the hint from Ask Jeeves insiders.
llama3.2:1b: Ask Jeeves has acquired Bloglines, a web log market that allows users to read, search, and share blogs.
The site has become popular due to its ability to aggregate blog entries using Really Simple Syndication (RSS) technology.
The acquisition is not driven by a desire to monetize the blog platform but rather by a need to enhance Ask Jeeves' search capabilities.
A spokesperson for Ask Jeeves stated that the service will help organize and index the database of 300 million blog entries, providing users with a more comprehensive web experience.
llama3.2:3b: Ask Jeeves acquires Bloglines, a website that allows users to read, search and share blogs, with plans not to change it but to use its 300 million archived articles to enhance its own index.
The acquisition follows other search site moves, such as Google's purchase of Blogger software.
Ask Jeeves aims to help people find information rather than writing it, and the deal will also drive blog entries to its portals.
gemma2:2b: Ask Jeeves has acquired Bloglines, a website that aggregates and organizes blogs for users.
The company plans to integrate Bloglines' 300 million articles into its search index, using RSS technology for efficient blog-related information retrieval.

While the acquisition will enhance their existing My Jeeves service, Ask Jeeves intends to focus on enhancing user discovery of information rather than directly monetizing the platform through immediate changes to Bloglines.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Ask Jeeves has acquired Bloglines, a website that aggregates blogs to help users find and follow their preferred topics.
Bloglines already has over 300 million articles, making it a valuable resource for search engines like Google and others.
The acquisition was planned but not revealed in advance.

Ask Jeeves sees the acquisition as a way to help people discover information they need without having to visit blogs themselves, which aligns with its own My Jeeves service that lets users find useful links directly on their websites.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Ask Jeeves has acquired Bloglines, a website that lets users easily follow blogs, to improve their content indexing for search purposes.
The move follows similar acquisitions by other search engines into blog-related technology.
Lanzone says Ask aims to use this acquisition to better organize and provide access to 300 million blog entries from the Bloglines database.
qwen2.5:3b: Ask Jeeves has acquired Bloglines, a popular website for managing subscriptions to blogs and web journals.
This move aims to enhance Ask Jeeves' content management capabilities by integrating their 300 million archived articles with Bloglines' technology.
The acquisition was not meant to change Bloglines but rather complement it within the broader context of search engines.
Bloglines is known for its user-friendly interface that allows subscribers to follow various blogs without manually visiting each site.
This service relies on RSS (Really Simple Syndication) technology, which enables efficient sharing and monitoring of new content from subscribed blogs.
The acquisition follows similar strategic moves by other search engine companies like Google and Yahoo in the blog publishing space.
Ask Jeeves intends to preserve Bloglines' existing functionality while adding their own indexing technology for a more comprehensive database of blog entries.
This integration will help users find information on blogs through unified search results across different platforms operated by Ask Jeeves, such as portals.
opencoder:1.5b: "Ask Jeeves joined the web log market to handle content from web journals or blogs.
Bloglines has become hugely popular due to its ability to provide users with a platform to read, search and share all the blogs they are interested in.
It has gained popularity because it lets users build a list of the blogs they want to follow without having to visit each journal site individually using RSS technology.
The acquisition also follows similar moves by other search sites like Google."
smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and objective, preserving key ideas and details while omitting unnecessary information.
Ask Jeeves has bought Bloglines to improve its content management system for web journals or blogs.
Bloglines has become popular as it gives users one place in which to read, search and share all the blogs they want to follow without having to visit each journal site individually.
The acquisition follows similar moves by other search sites.
Google acquired Pyra Labs, makers of the Blogger software, in 2003.
In 2004 MSN introduced its own blog system and Yahoo has tweaked its technology to do a better job of handling blog entries.
Jim Lanzone, vice president of search properties at Ask Jeeves in the US, said it did not acquire Bloglines just to get a foothold in the blog publishing world.
He said Ask Jeeves was much more interested in helping people find information they were looking for rather than helping them write it.
The universe of readers is vastly larger than the universe of writers.
It would be no surprise if Ask Jeeves did not acquire Bloglines just to get a foothold in the blog publishing world, but rather to help people discover new and useful content on the web.
RSS (Really Simple Syndication) is used by many blogs to let other sites know when new entries are made on their journals.

It would be no surprise if Ask Jeeves did not acquire Bloglines just to get a foothold in the blog publishing world, but rather to help people find information they were looking for and monitor the content of blogs.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Ask Jeeves acquired Bloglines, aiming to improve content handling for web journals or blogs through RSS, allowing users to build lists without visiting each site individually.
Google, M.S.N., and Yahoo adopted similar practices, while Mr. Lanzone focused on helping people find information, emphasizing a focus on discovering content rather than writing it.
The acquisition wasn't about changing Bloglines but about building a personal link collection service, integrating RSS for tracking blogs.
tinyllama:1.1b: The popular search engine company, Ask Jeeves, has acquired Bloglines, a website that archives and indexes web journal articles for users to read and share content, for an undisclosed amount.

The acquisition comes after similar moves by other internet companies like Google, MSN, and Yaoho in incorporating their blog systems into their search engine to offer better search results for readers.

Ask Jeeves aims to use the database of 300m articles to build up its own personalized web experience using its My Jeevies service, which allows users to customize their own experience and collect links from various sources.
Despite no immediate changes to Bloglines, the intention is to take Ask's time to figure out a business model not to monetize it immediately.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Bloglines website has become an integral part of the internet's vast blogosphere, providing users with a single point of access to all content from the world's most popular websites and platforms.

This acquisition by Ask Jeeves marks the company's entrance into the field of web publishing, where they will be utilizing their extensive knowledge of search engines to round out their existing Bloglines index.
Although the exact terms of the deal are not publicly known, it is believed that Ask Jeeves has paid a considerable sum for the acquisition.
This move by Ask Jeeves indicates their ambition to become a leading force in web publishing and will undoubtedly impact the way we access information on the internet.
phi:2.7b: Ask Jeeves has purchased Bloglines, a popular website for reading and sharing blogs.
The company plans to use the 300 million articles in its archive to enhance its index of web content.
The acquisition reflects an interest in helping people find information rather than encouraging them to write it.
My Jeeves, Ask's personalised search engine, will benefit from the blogosphere.
orca-mini:3b: Ask Jeeves has acquired the Bloglines website to improve its web log search capabilities.
Bloglines has become popular due to its ability to let users follow their favorite blogs without visiting each site individually.
The acquisition follows moves by other search engines to get a foothold in the blog publishing world.
Ask Jeeves plans to use Bloglines' database of 300 million blog entries to organize the web.
Jim Lanzone, vice president of search properties at Ask Jeeves, said the company does not plan to change Bloglines but will help organize the collection of blog entries.
hermes3:3b: Ask Jeeves acquires Bloglines, to enhance web log handling and use 300m archived blog entries for improved search capabilities.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Ask Jeeves purchased Bloglines to enhance its web journal and blog content management.
Bloglines allows users to read, search, and share their preferred blogs in one location through Really Simple Syndication (RSS).
While Ask Jeeves has no plans to change Bloglines significantly, it will utilize the site's archived 300 million articles to improve its index of the web.
The acquisition aligns with Ask Jeeves' focus on helping users find information instead of writing it.
No immediate changes are expected for Bloglines, and Ask Jeeves will help organize the 300 million blog entries using its own indexing technology.
stablelm2:1.6b: Ask Jeeves acquired Bloglines to improve content handling and expand its web index, using one million articles archived by Bloglines.
The popular blog reader allows users to build a list of blogs without visiting each site individually.
The acquisition follows similar moves by search sites such as Google, MSN, and Yahoo.
Ask Jeeves plans no immediate changes but intends to find the right business model for organizing the database of blog entries.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Ask Jeeves has acquired Bloglines, a popular platform for aggregating and reading web journals or blogs, to enhance its content management capabilities.
The deal leverages Bloglines' 300 million archived articles and RSS technology.
While Ask Jeeves plans no immediate changes to Bloglines, it aims to integrate the extensive database into its own indexing system.
This acquisition aligns with Ask Jeeves' mission to aid users in discovering information on the web rather than facilitating blog creation.
The move follows similar strategic purchases by Google (Blogger), MSN, and Yahoo (enhanced blogging features).

Vice President Jim Lanzone emphasized that this acquisition supports Ask Jeeves' My Jeeves service, which customizes users' web experiences, and will benefit the company's portals in driving information from blogs.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Ask Jeeves has acquired Bloglines to enhance its handling of blog content but does not plan immediate changes.
Bloglines is popular for allowing users to follow multiple blogs in one place using RSS technology.
The acquisition aligns with moves by other search companies like Google, MSN, and Yahoo.
Ask Jeeves aims to improve blog search and integrate Bloglines with its My Jeeves service rather than enter blog publishing.
The company will use Bloglines' 300 million archived articles to enhance its web index but will take time to determine a business model.
